results_summary: AA treatment mitigated cognitive decline, reduced neuroinflammation and oxidative stress, and activated antioxidant pathways (Nrf2/Keap1) while maintaining Sirt1/2 expression, leading to improved blood-brain barrier integrity and microvascular structure.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced bilateral common carotid artery occlusion (BCCAO).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Artemisia annua extract in mitigating the harmful side effects of pioglitazone (Actos) in male albino mice.
results_summary: The study found that concurrent treatment with Artemisia annua extract (4 g/kg) and pioglitazone (45 mg/kg) significantly improved hepatotoxicity, renal inflammation, hematological disorders, and histopathological changes caused by pioglitazone alone. Additionally, TNF-ɑ oncogene expression levels in bladder tissues decreased by 99.99% with the combined treatment.
population_specificity: Male albino mice
effective_dosage: 4 g/kg Artemisia annua extract, 45 mg/kg pioglitazone

study_goal: The researchers aimed to predict the active components and potential mechanisms of Artemisia annua in inhibiting the occurrence and development of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) using network pharmacology and molecular docking.
results_summary: The study identified key active ingredients (e.g., quercetin, luteolin) and 117 targets in A. annua, suggesting multi-component, multi-target, and multi-pathway mechanisms for AAA treatment. Molecular docking confirmed strong affinity between top active components and core disease targets.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cytotoxic effects of a hydroalcoholic extract of Artemisia annua on canine osteosarcoma cell lines, focusing on potential ferroptosis involvement.
results_summary: The extract showed dose-dependent cytotoxicity, induced lipid peroxidation, and altered cell cycle and iron content in canine osteosarcoma cells, suggesting ferroptosis activation. The study concluded that the extract has potential anticancer activity against drug-resistant canine osteosarcomas.
population_specificity: Canine osteosarcoma cell lines (OSCA-8 and OSCA-40)
effective_dosage: Extract contained 63.8 ± 3.4 μg/mL artemisinin (specific dosing not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of the MADS transcription factor AaSEP4 in regulating artemisinin biosynthesis in Artemisia annua.
results_summary: The study found that AaSEP4 activates the expression of AaGSW1 and key artemisinin biosynthesis genes, leading to significantly increased artemisinin content in AaSEP4-overexpressed plants. The results suggest AaSEP4 is a positive regulator of artemisinin production.
population_specificity: Artemisia annua plants (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Artemisia annua aqueous extract (AAE) on intestinal immune and antioxidative function in broilers.
results_summary: Dietary inclusion of AAE improved intestinal immune function by modulating cytokine levels and antioxidative function via the Nrf2 pathway, with optimal effects observed at doses of 1.12-1.38 g/kg.
population_specificity: One-day-old Arbor Acre broilers
effective_dosage: 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, and 2.0 g/kg AAE in the basal diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify potential inhibitors of SARS-CoV-2 main protease (Mpro) from bioactive compounds in Artemisia annua using computational techniques.
results_summary: The study identified several compounds (e.g., rhamnocitrin, isokaempferide, kaempferol) with strong docking scores and stability in the active site of Mpro, suggesting potential as COVID-19 drug candidates. These compounds also exhibited acceptable druglike properties and safety profiles.
population_specificity: Computational study (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Artemisia annua extracts on adipokine levels and insulin resistance in mice with high-fat-diet/streptozotocin-induced type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: All three types of Artemisia annua extracts significantly improved glucose tolerance, reduced insulin resistance, and modulated adipokine levels (decreased leptin and resistin, increased adiponectin), comparable to metformin.
population_specificity: Mice with HFD/STZ-induced type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: 100, 200, and 400 mg/kg of hot-water, cold-water, and alcoholic extracts (daily oral gavage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immunomodulatory and antioxidant potentials of polysaccharides from Artemisia annua and characterize their structural properties.
results_summary: The study found that polysaccharide fractions (AAP-1, AAP-2, AAP-3) exhibited significant antioxidant and immunostimulatory activities, with AAP-1 showing the highest efficacy in scavenging radicals and stimulating cytokine production (TNF-α and IL-6) in mouse macrophages. AAP-1 also demonstrated low toxicity at tested concentrations.
population_specificity: Mouse macrophages (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review tissue culture techniques and biotechnological approaches for enhancing artemisinin production in Artemisia annua, as well as its biosynthesis and metabolic engineering.
results_summary: The study highlights that artemisinin is produced in glandular trichomes and emphasizes the need for genetic overexpression and biotechnological methods (e.g., tissue culture, genetic engineering) to meet demand. It also discusses elicitation strategies and metabolic engineering to optimize artemisinin yield.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how phosphorus levels and arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi influence Artemisia annua growth, mineral uptake, and artemisinin production.
results_summary: Higher phosphorus levels reduced mycorrhizal colonization and artemisinin concentration, while the fungus primarily affected root growth and nutrient uptake. The lowest phosphate level yielded the highest artemisinin concentration, regardless of mineral uptake.
population_specificity: Artemisia annua plants grown in controlled conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to uncover the role of the AabZIP1-AaMYC2 transcriptional module in enhancing artemisinin biosynthesis and drought tolerance in Artemisia annua.
results_summary: The study found that AabZIP1 promotes artemisinin production by upregulating AaMYC2, which activates key biosynthesis genes, and also enhances wax biosynthesis and drought tolerance. Overexpression of AabZIP1 significantly increased artemisinin and wax production, while RNAi suppression decreased these traits.
population_specificity: Artemisia annua plants (in vitro or controlled environment study).
study_duration: Not specified (short-term water-withholding or ABA treatment mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether foliar application of the synthetic strigolactone analog GR24 could enhance the growth, photosynthesis, and artemisinin production in Artemisia annua.
results_summary: The study found that GR24 application improved plant biomass, photosynthesis-related attributes, and glandular trichome characteristics, with 4 µM GR24 showing the most significant enhancement in artemisinin content and yield compared to untreated plants.
population_specificity: Artemisia annua plants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the components of Artemisia annua essential oil (AEO) and its effects on osteoclast proliferation and differentiation in vitro, as well as explore potential mechanisms.
results_summary: AEO inhibited osteoclast differentiation by reducing TRAF6 activation, affecting the MAPK and NF-κB pathways, and decreasing the expression of osteoclast-related genes. The study identified key components of AEO but did not report adverse effects on cell proliferation at tested concentrations.
population_specificity: Mouse RAW264.7 cells (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Volume ratios of 1:4000, 1:5000, and 1:6000 (specific concentrations not provided)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the biological processes and mechanisms by which Artemisia annua's active components (casticin and chrysosplenol D) induce apoptosis in non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cells.
results_summary: CAS and CHD inhibited NSCLC cell proliferation in a time- and dose-dependent manner, significantly inducing apoptosis. They likely induce DNA damage by binding to topo IIα-DNA and reducing topo IIα activity, revealing a novel anticancer mechanism.
population_specificity: NSCLC cells (A549 and H1299 cell lines)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different LED light spectra affect the production of bioactive compounds in Artemisia annua and its antimalarial activity against Plasmodium falciparum.
results_summary: White and blue LED spectra increased leaf fresh weight, artemisinin, and artemisinic acid production, enhancing antimalarial activity, while red light reduced bioactive compound production. Extracts from white and blue treatments showed 2-4 times higher anti-Plasmodium activity compared to red light or greenhouse-grown plants.
population_specificity: Artemisia annua plants grown under controlled LED light conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate the nematicidal constituents of Artemisia annua L. and their effectiveness against Meloidogyne incognita.
results_summary: Artemisinic acid (ArA) and dihydroartemisinic acid (DHArA) demonstrated strong nematicidal activity in vitro and in pot experiments, with ArA showing higher potency. The compounds caused toxic effects on nematodes, including body shrinkage and membrane system disruption, and ArA reduced glutathione content in nematodes.
population_specificity: Meloidogyne incognita second-stage juveniles (J2s)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Artemisia annua water extract (AWE) on a DNCB-induced atopic dermatitis (AD) mouse model and explore its potential mechanisms.
results_summary: AWE significantly reduced AD-like symptoms in mice, including skin dermatitis severity and ear edema, by suppressing inflammatory markers (IgE, IL-4, IL-6, IL-13, IL-17, TNF-α, TSLP) and inhibiting p38 MAPK and NF-κB pathways.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice with DNCB-induced atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Artemisia annua extract against Schistosoma mansoni adult worms in vitro and its impact on tissue damage in hamsters.
results_summary: Artemisia annua at concentrations of 125, 250, and 500 μg/ml was highly effective against adult Schistosoma mansoni worms in vitro. In vivo, it reduced granuloma size and caused damage to worm eggs in hamster liver and spleen tissues.
population_specificity: Schistosoma mansoni adult worms (in vitro) and hamsters (in vivo).
effective_dosage: 31.25, 62.5, 125, 250, and 500 μg/ml (in vitro); unspecified for in vivo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify active components and mechanisms of Artemisia annua in treating COVID-19 through network analysis, molecular docking, and simulations.
results_summary: The study found that Artemisia annua may regulate inflammatory responses and apoptosis in COVID-19, with quercetin and kaempferol identified as effective candidates targeting MAPK1 and TP53, respectively. Molecular docking and simulations supported their binding efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Artemisia annua could effectively treat experimentally induced leucocytozoonosis in chickens compared to sulfadimethoxine and a control group.
results_summary: Artemisia annua improved weight gain, reduced parasite concentrations, and decreased symptoms like pale comb and green feces, with recovery rates comparable to sulfadimethoxine. The experimental groups showed earlier recovery and better clinical outcomes than the control group.
population_specificity: Chickens experimentally infected with Leucocytozoon caulleryi.
study_duration: At least 31 days (until all animals recovered).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of aqueous and alcoholic extracts of Artemisia annua on insulin resistance in high-fat diet/STZ-induced diabetic mice.
results_summary: All Artemisia annua extracts significantly reduced serum levels of free fatty acids, TNF-alpha, IL-6, LDL/HDL ratio, and HOMA-IR in diabetic mice, with the 400 mg/kg cold-water extract being more effective than metformin in reducing TNF-alpha and IL-6.
population_specificity: High-fat diet/streptozotocin-induced diabetic mice
effective_dosage: 100, 200, and 400 mg/kg body weight of water (hot and cold) and alcoholic extracts

study_goal: The researchers aimed to model the current and future global distribution of Artemisia annua and evaluate the impacts of human activities and climate change on its suitable habitats and protection status.
results_summary: The study found that A. annua's main distribution areas are concentrated in mid-latitudes, with human modifications reducing suitable habitats. Future projections suggest expansion inland due to climate change, but Europe is the most affected continent. Protection status scores for A. annua are low across all continents.
population_specificity: Global distribution (not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential role of uncontrolled Artemisia annua use in the emergence of resistance to artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) for malaria and COVID-19 prevention in sub-Saharan Africa.
results_summary: The study suggests that uncontrolled use of Artemisia annua for malaria and COVID-19 prevention in sub-Saharan Africa may contribute to resistance against ACTs, potentially rendering them ineffective in the future. The abstract highlights factors like counterfeit drugs, poor adherence, and dosing errors as contributors to drug resistance.
population_specificity: Sub-Saharan African region (malaria-endemic areas)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Artemisia annua hot-water extracts against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and kappa.
results_summary: The study found that A. annua cultivars (A3, BUR, MED, SAM) were effective against all tested SARS-CoV-2 variants, with IC50 and IC90 values indicating potency. Cell toxicity was insignificant at doses ≤50 μg dry weight.
population_specificity: Vero E6 cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: IC50 values ranged from 11.0 to 67.7 μg dry weight (DW), IC90 values ranged from 59.5 to 160.6 μg DW.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Artemisia annua and its compounds exhibit anti-SARS-CoV-2 properties by inhibiting viral proteins and modulating host immune responses.
results_summary: Fourteen in silico studies suggested that A. annua compounds may inhibit SARS-CoV-2 by targeting viral-host proteins, potentially blocking viral attachment, replication, and transcription. The herb may also modulate immune responses to combat COVID-19.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico and literature-based study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how alternative splicing (AS), particularly intron retention (IR) isoforms in Artemisia annua, responds to light regulation and its potential role in regulating sesquiterpenoid biosynthesis.
results_summary: The study identified 5,854 IR isoforms, with IR being the most common AS mechanism (48.48%). Light treatment (blue and red) significantly increased up-regulated IR isoforms compared to down-regulated ones, and 10 genes in the artemisinin biosynthetic pathway produced 16 differentially expressed IR isoforms, suggesting light-induced IR isoforms may regulate sesquiterpenoid biosynthesis.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or plant-based study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the artemisinin content in Artemisia annua, assess its in vitro biological activity against SARS-CoV-2, and evaluate its potential as a treatment via molecular modeling.
results_summary: Artemisinin showed significant inhibition of SARS-CoV-2 3CL protease activity but not Spike/ACE-2 binding. It also demonstrated immunosuppressive effects on TNF-α production in a dose-dependent manner, with cell viability remaining high (94%).
population_specificity: HEK293T cell line and THP-1 cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: EC50 > 50 μM (EC45) for SARS-CoV-2 Spike pseudovirus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Artemisia annua, artemisinin, and artesunate against Babesia microti in mice and six Candida species in vitro.
results_summary: The study found that Artemisia annua, artesunate, and artemisinin were ineffective in reducing parasitemia in B. microti-infected mice and showed limited, unsustainable growth inhibition against Candida species.
population_specificity: Mice infected with Babesia microti and in vitro cultures of six Candida species.
effective_dosage: 100 µg artemisinin/kg body weight daily for mice; up to 180 µM artemisinin for Candida cultures.
study_duration: 6 days for mice; variable for Candida cultures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Artemisia annua-derived compounds, particularly artemisinin, to inhibit SARS-CoV-2 spike protein binding to host receptors using in silico molecular docking and dynamics simulations.
results_summary: Artemisinin showed the lowest binding energy with SARS-CoV-2 spike proteins (6VXX and 6VYB), suggesting strong potential to prevent viral interaction with ACE-2 receptors. All tested phytocompounds, including artemisinin, were non-toxic and non-carcinogenic.
population_specificity: In silico study (no human or animal subjects).
study_duration: Molecular dynamics simulation was performed for 50ns.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how aging affects artemisinin (ART) biosynthesis in Artemisia annua by analyzing small RNA and transcriptome changes in leaves of different ages.
results_summary: The study found that aging increases ART biosynthesis by upregulating key genes (ADS, CYP71AV1, ADH1, DBR2, ALDH1) and transcription factors (AaERF1, AaORA, AaWRKY1), while miR156 and related miRNAs decrease.
population_specificity: Leaves of 2-week-old and 3-month-old Artemisia annua plants.
study_duration: Not applicable (comparative analysis of plant ages)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the regulatory mechanisms linking JA and ABA signaling with artemisinin biosynthesis in Artemisia annua through transcription factors.
results_summary: The study identified AaTCP15 as a key transcription factor that activates artemisinin biosynthesis genes in response to JA and ABA, forming a regulatory module with AaORA and AaGSW1 to synergistically enhance production.
population_specificity: In vitro and molecular study (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize AaMYB15 as a negative regulator of artemisinin biosynthesis in Artemisia annua and explore its role in the regulation network mediated by light and jasmonic acid (JA).
results_summary: The study found that AaMYB15 negatively regulates artemisinin biosynthesis by repressing the transcriptional activity of AaORA, leading to decreased expression of key enzyme genes and reduced artemisinin content in transgenic A. annua. AaMYB15 expression was induced by dark and JA treatment, suggesting its role in light and JA-mediated regulation.
population_specificity: Transgenic Artemisia annua plants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active ingredients and mechanisms of Artemisia annua in treating hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) using network pharmacology and molecular docking.
results_summary: The study identified 19 active ingredients in Artemisia annua and 25 HCC-related targets, with key targets (EGFR, ESR1, CCND1, MYC, EGF, PTGS2) involved in tumor cell proliferation, apoptosis, angiogenesis, and metastasis. Molecular docking confirmed quercetin's stable binding to EGFR, suggesting multicomponent, multipath, and multitarget antitumor potential.
population_specificity: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vitro inhibitory activity of Artemisia annua and its bioactive compounds against Babesia duncani.
results_summary: Artemisia annua and its compounds (artemisinin, artesunate, artemether) showed good in vitro inhibitory activity against B. duncani, with IC50 values comparable or lower than currently used drugs. Artemether at 8× IC50 prevented regrowth in subculture.
population_specificity: In vitro study using the hamster erythrocyte model.
effective_dosage: IC50 values: artemisinin (14 μM), artesunate (7.4 μM), artemether (7.8 μM).
study_duration: Three days for artemether subculture test.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the physio-biochemical mechanisms of exogenous hydrogen sulphide (H₂S) in alleviating copper (Cu) stress in Artemisia annua.
results_summary: Excess Cu reduced growth, photosynthesis, and antioxidant activity in A. annua, while H₂S application restored these parameters, reduced Cu content, and increased artemisinin production.
population_specificity: Artemisia annua plants under controlled experimental conditions.
effective_dosage: Cu levels (20, 40 mg·kg⁻¹), H₂S treatment (200 µM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a water extract of Artemisia annua (WEAA) could prevent or treat hepatic lipid accumulation and liver damage in NAFLD models.
results_summary: WEAA inhibited lipid accumulation in HepG2 cells and protected them from oxidative stress by activating antioxidant enzymes. In mice, WEAA reduced weight gain, hepatic lipid accumulation, and plasma triglyceride and liver enzyme levels.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (human hepatocarcinoma cell line) and high-fat diet-fed mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the traditional uses, pharmacological activities, and growing importance of Artemisia annua, including its known and newly discovered biological effects.
results_summary: The study confirmed traditional uses of Artemisia annua in treating conditions like malaria, jaundice, and bacterial dysentery, and identified new biological activities such as anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antitumour, and nephroprotective effects. The species is also gaining significance in the cosmetics industry.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad review of traditional and pharmacological applications)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the phytochemicals, antioxidants, antimicrobial properties, and synergistic potential of methanolic and petroleum ether extracts of Artemisia annua against bacterial and fungal pathogens.
results_summary: Methanolic extract showed higher antioxidant potential than petroleum ether extract. Both extracts exhibited potent inhibitory activity against Candida strains and synergistic effects with antibiotics, reducing MIC by 4 to 264 folds. A sub-fraction of the extracts revealed 13 major phytocompounds, with 2-Propenoic acid and ridecyl ester being the most prominent.
population_specificity: Bacterial and fungal pathogens (e.g., S. aureus, E. coli, Candida strains)
interactions: Synergistic effects noted with antibacterial and antifungal antibiotics

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore approaches to improve artemisinin (ART) production from Artemisia annua to address supply instability and high costs.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the challenges in ART production, including low natural abundance and cost inefficiencies in heterologous biosynthesis and semi-synthesis, suggesting the need for alternative methods to supplement agricultural production.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Artemisia annua's potential as a bio-pesticide against Glyphodes pyloalis Walker and its effects on larval physiology and immunity.
results_summary: The essential oil of Artemisia annua significantly inhibited digestive enzymes, reduced nutrient levels, impaired immune responses, and caused midgut degeneration in treated larvae. Adult ovaries also showed structural abnormalities, suggesting potential for pest control.
population_specificity: Glyphodes pyloalis Walker larvae and emerging adults.
effective_dosage: LC50 of 0.652% W/V (oral) and 2.585 μL/L air (fumigation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the longer-term safety and efficacy of Arthrem® (ART) in managing osteoarthritis symptoms over six months following a pilot trial.
results_summary: ART was well tolerated for up to nine months, and improvements in pain reduction observed in the pilot study were maintained over six months. The supplement showed clinically relevant efficacy in managing osteoarthritis symptoms.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis of the hip or knee who completed the initial 12-week pilot study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety and efficacy of Artemisia annua extract (Arthrem) in reducing pain, stiffness, and functional limitation in patients with osteoarthritis of the hip or knee.
results_summary: The study found that the low-dose Artemisia annua extract (150 mg twice daily) significantly improved WOMAC scores and reduced VAS pain scores compared to placebo, while the high dose showed no significant effects. The supplement was well-tolerated, with no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: 42 patients with osteoarthritis of the hip or knee.
effective_dosage: 150 mg twice daily (low dose) and 300 mg twice daily (high dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Artichoke Extract (ALE) supplementation could improve insulin resistance and glycemic parameters in individuals with the TT genotype of the rs7903146 variant of TCF7L2.
results_summary: Two RCTs found that ALE supplementation significantly decreased insulin concentration and improved insulin resistance in the TT genotype of the rs7903146 variant of TCF7L2. However, the broader study context showed mixed results regarding TCF7L2's modification effects on glycemic parameters in response to lifestyle factors.
population_specificity: Individuals with the TT genotype of the rs7903146 variant of TCF7L2 (specific to insulin resistance and glycemic parameters).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze existing studies on the antioxidant effects of artichoke extract in human, animal, and in vitro models.
results_summary: In vitro studies supported artichoke's antioxidant effects, while limited clinical trials showed minimal or no improvement in antioxidant status. Animal studies demonstrated significant increases in antioxidant enzyme levels (e.g., superoxide dismutase, catalase) and reductions in oxidative stress markers (e.g., malondialdehyde).
population_specificity: Human, animal (induced disease models), and in vitro systems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a nutraceutical containing artichoke extract on lipid and glucose metabolism, adipokines, and systemic inflammation in overweight dyslipidemic subjects.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in triglycerides, LDL-C, and other metabolic markers in active-treated groups, with high-dose treatment showing additional benefits in reducing inflammation and improving adipokine profiles. Effects persisted at 24-week follow-up.
population_specificity: Overweight dyslipidemic subjects (n=90)
effective_dosage: Combined nutraceutical containing chlorogenic acid from dry artichoke extract (exact dosage not specified); administered as two pills (active or placebo) or one pill of each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if artichoke extract supplementation affects human lipid parameters, particularly total cholesterol, LDL-C, HDL-C, and triglycerides.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that artichoke extract significantly reduced total cholesterol, LDL-C, and triglycerides, but did not significantly alter HDL-C levels. The LDL-lowering effect was more pronounced in individuals with higher baseline LDL-C concentrations.
population_specificity: 702 subjects across 9 randomized controlled trials (RCTs).

study_goal: To assess the efficacy and safety of Artichoke Leaf Extract (ALE) in treating hypercholesterolaemia.
results_summary: ALE showed a statistically significant reduction in total cholesterol levels compared to placebo in three trials, though the evidence is not yet convincing due to methodological shortcomings. Adverse events were mild, transient, and infrequent.
population_specificity: Patients with hypercholesterolaemia.
study_duration: 12 weeks in one trial, 42 ± 3 days in another.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the presence and removal efficiency of artificial sweeteners (ACE, SAC, ASP, NEO) in sewage and drinking water treatment systems.
results_summary: The study found that SPE-HPLC effectively detected artificial sweeteners in water, with high occurrence rates in domestic sewage and varying removal efficiencies (67.7%-100.0%) during treatment processes. No sweeteners were detected in the water supply network.
population_specificity: Sewage and drinking water treatment systems in two cities in Zhejiang Province.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the genotoxic and protective effects of artichoke leaf extract on human liver cells (HepG2) and its ability to modulate DNA damage induced by hydrogen peroxide.
results_summary: Artichoke extract showed genotoxic effects on HepG2 cells after 1- and 24-hour treatments. Lower concentrations (0.62, 1.25, and 2.5 mg/mL) exhibited protective effects against hydrogen peroxide-induced DNA damage in pretreatment, while only the lowest concentration (0.62 mg/mL) was protective in simultaneous and post-treatment protocols. The highest concentration (5.0 mg/mL) increased hydrogen peroxide genotoxicity in simultaneous treatment.
population_specificity: Human hepatocyte cultures (HepG2 cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of aspartame and acesulfame potassium (ace-K) on the growth and metabolic pathways of gut commensal Escherichia coli.
results_summary: The study found that NAS (aspartame and ace-K) modulated the growth of E. coli and altered the expression of key metabolic genes related to glucose, nucleotide, and fatty acid metabolism, which may impact gut microbiota composition and function.
population_specificity: Gut commensal Escherichia coli (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a sensitive method for detecting six artificial sweeteners in surface waters using TF-SPME and HPLC.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a method with high sensitivity (LODs 0.004–0.038 ng mL-1) and reproducibility, detecting artificial sweeteners in river water downstream of wastewater treatment plants at concentrations of 0.03–20.3 ng mL-1.
population_specificity: Surface water samples from Grand River, Ontario, Canada.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a passive treatment system containing zero-valent iron and biochar in removing artificial sweeteners and other emerging contaminants from water.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the treatment system effectively removed four artificial sweeteners (acesulfame-K, sucralose, saccharin, and cyclamate) from water, with removal rates and constants calculated for different media configurations.
population_specificity: Water samples containing artificial sweeteners and other contaminants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of pure sucralose and aspartame, at common consumption doses, on glucose metabolism in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in glucose metabolism or insulin sensitivity after daily consumption of pure sucralose or aspartame for 2 weeks compared to baseline values in healthy participants.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (10 females, 7 males; age 24 ± 6.8 years; BMI 22.9 ± 2.5 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 0.425 g aspartame (14% ADI) and 0.136 g sucralose (20% ADI) daily, mixed with water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the degradation kinetics, pathways, and toxicity of artificial sweeteners (acesulfame and sucralose) using the UV/persulfate advanced oxidation process in wastewater.
results_summary: The UV/PS process effectively removed ACE and SUC, with contributions from UV photolysis, hydroxyl radicals, and sulfate radicals. However, toxicity evaluation showed that treated ASs increased toxicity in C. carpio liver, though prolonged treatment and freshwater recovery reduced this effect.
population_specificity: Wastewater effluents and C. carpio (fish) liver.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a low digestible carbohydrate (LDC) diet could mitigate glucose metabolism disorders induced by prolonged consumption of artificial sweeteners (acesulfame potassium or saccharin) in mice.
results_summary: Prolonged artificial sweetener consumption led to glucose intolerance, insulin resistance, and altered carbohydrate absorption, but an LDC diet improved these metabolic dysfunctions by modulating sweet taste receptors and glucose transporters.
population_specificity: Mice
study_duration: 12 weeks (artificial sweetener administration) + 6 weeks (LDC diet intervention)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a passive treatment system (using zero-valent iron, biochar, or a mixture) in removing artificial sweeteners from water.
results_summary: The passive treatment system partially removed artificial sweeteners acesulfame-K and saccharin (~110 μg L-1), with zero-valent iron (ZVI) being more effective for acesulfame-K and sucralose (>76% removal), while biochar (BC) showed greater removal of saccharin. Cyclamate was not removed in any columns.
population_specificity: Environmental water samples (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the input, occurrence, and distribution of artificial sweeteners in coastal wastewater treatment plants and their receiving coastal waters.
results_summary: The study found that acesulfame and sucralose persisted in both wastewater treatment plants and coastal waters, with higher removal efficiencies for saccharine and cyclamate. The highest concentrations were detected in a sewage-impacted estuary, suggesting their potential as sewage-pollution markers.
population_specificity: Coastal wastewater treatment plants and receiving coastal waters in Cadiz Bay, SW Spain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the applicability of artificial sweeteners (specifically acesulfame) and iodinated X-ray contrast media as tracers to detect wastewater impact on stream chemistry.
results_summary: The study found that acesulfame (ACE) was consistently detected in surface water samples, indicating its chemical stability and widespread presence due to wastewater effluents. DTZ and IOP were also identified as potential tracers, with varying concentrations linked to wastewater impact.
population_specificity: Wastewater treatment plant effluents and surface water samples in Germany.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (environmental concentrations of ACE ranged between 0.5 μg/L and 1 μg/L).
study_duration: Not specified (sampling was conducted as 2-h composites).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the removal of artificial sweeteners (ASWs) in wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) and their effects on activated sludge.
results_summary: The study found that cyclamate (CYC) and saccharin (SAC) were completely removed, sucralose (SUC) was persistent, and acesulfame (ACE) removal was greater in lab-scale reactors than full-scale WWTPs. ASWs reduced microbial activity (ATP and TTC-DHA) and altered microbial communities, with ACE having the greatest impact.
population_specificity: Activated sludge in sequencing batch reactors (SBRs) and a full-scale WWTP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the extent to which septic systems contribute artificial sweeteners to groundwater aquifers in rural areas and assess their presence in domestic wells and groundwater seeps.
results_summary: Approximately 30% of groundwater samples had detectable levels of artificial sweeteners, indicating septic system effluent contamination. Acesulfame was used to estimate septic effluent contribution, revealing 3.4–13.6% of domestic wells and 2.0–4.7% of groundwater seeps had ≥1% septic-derived water. No correlation was found between acesulfame and nutrient concentrations.
population_specificity: Rural residents relying on the Lake Algonquin Sand Aquifer in the Nottawasaga River Watershed, ON, Canada.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of micropollutants, including artificial sweeteners, from wastewater treatment plants and on-site sewage treatment facilities on natural waters.
results_summary: The study found that sucralose, an artificial sweetener, was a dominant micropollutant in sites affected by wastewater treatment plants, constituting 27% of the total micropollutants. The composition profiles varied significantly between sites affected by different sources.
population_specificity: Natural waters within a Swedish catchment, including sites affected by wastewater treatment plants and on-site sewage treatment facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify suitable wastewater indicators, including artificial sweeteners, for evaluating wastewater impact in the Pearl River Delta region.
results_summary: The study found sucralose and cyclamate as conservative and liable wastewater indicators, respectively, based on their occurrence and removal rates in wastewater treatment plants and surface water.
population_specificity: Wastewater treatment plants and surface water in the Pearl River Delta region, south China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the fate of artificial sweeteners (SAC, CYC, ACE, SUC) in pig farms and neighboring farmland, including their presence in feed, manure, wastewater, soil, and vegetables.
results_summary: SAC, CYC, and ACE were widely detected in samples, with high removal efficiencies (>90%) in wastewater treatment. ASs degraded quickly in soil (half-lives of 2.7-12.3 days) and were absorbed by plants when soil concentrations were high.
population_specificity: Pig farm environment (feed, manure, wastewater) and neighboring farmland (soil, vegetables) in Tianjin, China.
effective_dosage: Not specified (mass loadings in pig feed: SAC 311 kg/year, CYC 59.1 kg/year, ACE 17.1 kg/year).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether food additives, including artificial sweeteners, interfere with the acquisition of oral tolerance and increase the risk of food allergies.
results_summary: Saccharin sodium and a mixture of food additives inhibited oral tolerance acquisition in mice, leading to food allergy symptoms (hypothermia, allergic diarrhea) and elevated OVA-specific IgE. The additives also altered antigen-presenting cell migration and reduced regulatory T cell proportions in mesenteric lymph nodes.
population_specificity: Mice (murine model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the removal efficiency of four artificial sweeteners (acesulfame, sucralose, cyclamate, and saccharin) in wastewater treatment plants and evaluate advanced removal methods.
results_summary: The study found that artificial sweeteners were detected in wastewater influent, with higher concentrations in winter. The A2/O process was most effective for biodegradation, and UV/PDS was highly efficient for further removal. Adsorption methods showed varying effectiveness, with resin outperforming granular activated carbon for most sweeteners.
population_specificity: Wastewater treatment plants in China using SBR, oxidation ditch, and A2/O processes.
